title: ICBC provides CFA 80.75 billion loan for Phase 1 of San Pedro University Construction Project
description: On September 10, 2018, Envol Partenariats-Côte d'Ivoire (Envol Partenariats CI)— a subsidiary of the Senegalese group Envol Immobilier — and the Government of Cote d'Ivoire a signed public-private partnership (PPP) agreement for Phase 1 of the San Pedro University Construction Project. Under the terms of the 16-year concession agreement, Envol Partenariats-Côte d'Ivoire was given responsibility for the financing, construction, and operation of the construction of the University of San Pedro (Universite de San Pedro, USP, 圣佩德罗大学). The Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) agreed to provide a loan to Envol Partenariats CI for Phase 1 of San Pedro University Construction Project. The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the borrower to finance 85% of the cost of a CFA 95 billion (EUR 128 million) EPC contract between Envol Partenariats-Côte d'Ivoire and Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative (WIETC). The Government of Cote d'Ivoire agreed to issue a sovereign guarantee in support of this loan. To facilitate repayment of the ICBC loan, the Government of Cote d'Ivoire also agreed to pay rent to Envol Partenariats CI over a period of fifteen years.   The purpose of the project was to construct a new university town — consisting of consists of more than 100 buildings — in the city of San-Pedro (San Pedro).  The 302-hectare project includes teaching spaces, recreational, leisure, sports and cultural spaces, a library, an accommodation campus with a kitchen and restaurants. The San Pedro University Construction Project is divided into four phases, with a total land area of 500,584.31m2 and a total building area of 205,071.33m2. Upon completion, San Pedro University is expected to accommodate 20,000 students. Phase 1 involved the construction of 40 buildings that can accommodate 3,000 students. Weihai International Economic & Technical Cooperative (WIETC) was the general EPC contractor responsible for Phase 1 implementation. However, there is also some evidence that China Communications Construction Company, Ltd. (CCCC), China Railway 19th Bureau Group Co Ltd, China Railway Urban Construction Group Co., Ltd. (中铁城建集团有限公司) were involved in Phase 1 implementation.   A foundation stone laying ceremony took place on November 30, 2018. When the Ivorian Minister of Education inspected the project site in February 2020, construction activities were underway. The project encountered implementation delays in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. However, construction was completed on March 19, 2021. A grand opening ceremony for the University of San-Pedro subsequently took place on October 19, 2021.
staff_comments: 1. The Chinese project title is 科特迪瓦圣佩德罗大学项目 or 科特迪瓦圣佩德罗体育场馆项目 or 科特迪瓦圣佩德罗体育场项目. The French project title is Nouveau Campus de San-Pédro or Les travaux de construction de l'Université de San Pedro or Project de la première tranche de l'université de San Pedro « USP-I» or Nouveau campus de San-Pédro 2. The overall project cost is 95 billion CFA, so 85% is 80.75 billion CFA (see: CNP-PPP pg. 5-6). 3. The PPP agreement (16-year concession agreement) was approved by the Council of Ministers on September 12, 2018. 4. It is unclear if ICBC only agreed to finance Phase 1 or Phase 1 and subsequent phases of the project. Several media reports indicate that ICBC ‘abruptly withdrew’ from the San Pedro University Construction Project in March 2021, forcing Envol Partenariats CI to turn to Nigeria's UBA and BNI as alternative lenders. However, given that Phase 1 was complete as of March 19, 2021, it seems unlikely that ICBC’s loan commitment for Phase 1 was suspended or canceled. It seems more likely that ICBC decided not to finance subsequent phases of the project. However, this issue merits further investigation. 5. The ICBC loan for Phase 1 of the San Pedro University Construction Project is not included in the Chinese Loans to Africa (CLA) database that is managed by the Global Development Policy Center at Boston University and SAIS-CARI.

title: China donates container inspection equipment to Noé, Cote d'Ivoire (Linked to Project ID#66003)
description: On March 24, 2018, China donated container scanning equipment to the Government of Cote d'Ivoire for use in Noé, a border town next to Ghana. The Chinese Government granted an unknown amount of funds to hire Tongfang Weishi Technology Co. (NUCTECH) to manufacture this technology, including a mobile X-ray inspection system. The purpose of this donation is to assist Ivorian law enforcement and inspect cargo crossing the border from Ghana. title: Chinese Government funds the 2018 Seminar on Rice Cultivation in Cote d'Ivoire
description: On July 4, 2018, the opening ceremony for a seminar on rice cultivation technology (Seminaire 2018 sur les Techniques de la Culture du Riz or 水稻技术培训班) was held in Abidjan, Cote d'Ivoire. The one-month-long training course was sponsored by the Chinese Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), co-run by China's Foreign Economic Cooperation Center under their Ministry of Agriculture and Cote d'Ivoire's National Rice Development Office under their Ministry of Agriculture, and taught by various Chinese experts. The training includes modules such as Chinese cultural experience, theoretical study, on-site teaching, professional inspection, and interactive exchanges. The value of this training is unknown. The 80 students received completion certificates during the graduation ceremony held on August 2, 2018, in Abidjan.  China conducted this training in 2019 (Project ID#71215), 2017 (Project ID#65997), and 2016 (Project ID#65981).

title: China funds Satellite Television project for 500 villages in Cote d'Ivoire (Linked to Umbrella Project ID#57618)
description: In 2015, during the Johannesburg Summit for the Forum on China-Africa Cooperation (FOCAC), President Xi Jinping announced the "Access to satellite TV in 10,000 African villages" project (万村通卫星数字电视项目). StarTimes (四达时代) is implementing the project in rural regions of 25 different African countries (Umbrella Project ID#57618), including Cote d'Ivoire, and it is all paid for by the Chinese Government in the form of free assistance.   On June 15, 2018, the Chinese Ambassador and Ivorian Minister of Foreign Affairs signed an exchange of letters committing to carry out this project for 500 villages in Cote d'Ivoire. StarTimes will install necessary infrastructure for digital terrestrial television including satellite dishes, home decoders, 1,000 sets of solar-powered projection TV systems, 500 sets of digital TV all-in-one terminals, 10,000 sets of set-top boxes, and satellite reception systems for 500 villages nationwide. The project was officially launched on October 24, 2019, in Abidjan. As of October 2021, many villages in the country are covered by the project. The project seems to still be in implementation stage.
staff_comments: As of November 2021, many villages in the country are covered by the project. However, it is not indicated that the project has finished. Therefore, it is assumed that it is still being implemented, as the Chinese crew has encountered many difficulties to travel through isolated villages.

title: ICBC Standard Bank contributes to EUR 577 million syndicated loan to help Ivorian Refining Company (SIR) refinance its debts and invest in current operations
description: In 2017, AFC was appointed by the Government of Cote D’Ivoire — represented by the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Energy, the Ministry of Budget and Société Ivoirienne de Raffinage (SIR) — as Sole Mandated Lead Arranger (MLA) to raise a long term debt facility of approximately EUR 670 million to uniformly extend the tenor and reduce the interest rate of the SIR’s existing liabilities. Then, in December 2018, Société Ivoirienne de Raffinage (SIR) — an oil refinery in Abidjan that is majority-owned by the Government of Cote D’Ivoire and a number of international oil companies — signed an EUR 577 million (CFA 378.5 billion) syndicated loan agreement with six banks. The members of the lending syndicate included Africa Finance Corporation (AFC), Deutsche Bank, ICBC Standard Bank, United Bank for Africa, NSIA Bank, and Bridge Bank. AFC — the sole mandated lead arranger — contributed EUR 192 million.   The syndicated loan, which is structured as levy-backed senior secured debt, has a euro tranche with a 9-year maturity and a West African CFA franc tranche with a 7-year maturity. The other borrowing terms of the loan are unknown. However, it is known that the borrower (SIR) was to use the proceeds of the loan to refinance its debts and invest in current operations. The Government of Cote D’Ivoire issued a sovereign guarantee in support of the loan. SIR is the sole oil refinery in Cote d’Ivoire and it is charged with the responsibility for refining crude oil, and sale of resulting products to the local Ivorian market, and for export to West African countries and the international market. It has an annual output of 3.8 million tons of refined crude oil products, making it the largest crude oil refinery in West Africa. It is considered to be one of Cote d'Ivoire's most strategic assets.
staff_comments: 1. The monetary value of ICBC Standard Bank’s contribution to the EUR 577 million syndicated loan is unknown. However, it is known that AFC contributed EUR 192 million, so for the time being, AidData assumes that the other members of the syndicate (including ICBC Standard Bank) contributed equal amounts (EUR 77 million). 2. This loan is coded as collateralized because it is described by the sole Mandated Lead Arranger as levy-backed senior secured debt. 3. Norton Rose Fullbright and Billé-Aka, Brizoua-Bi & Associés were the counsels for the lenders. 4. One source refers to the purpose of the loan as to ‘repay historical obligations on crude oil supply, provide a long tenured facility and reduce the interest rate of SIR's stock debt.’ 5. ICBC Standard Bank, Plc is majority owned by the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Limited (ICBC).
